story:
Natif de la ville de Longvic en Bourgogne, ma destinée est dans un parcours plein de richesse culturelle dans divers milieux sociaux avec une orientation professionnelle plutôt technique et scientifique.

Le présent projet est né de la volonté de produire et de crée de la valeur autour de moi dans une dynamique d'évolution sociétale basée non pas sur la notion de consommateur mais de conso-producteur. C'est ainsi qu'après l’amélioration de mes compétences personnelles et professionnelles, en tant qu'ingénieur chef de projet au sein de centre de R&D (Recherche et Développement) chez divers constructeurs de moyen de transports routiers, j'ai décidé de créer une société fin 2014 (MEDINE Technology) pour en faire l'outil d'innovation et de développement d'une gamme de produits combinant utilité sanitaire et confort thermique.

Tout projet est, en fait, une action et pour que l'action produise "bien et utile" elle doit être précédée par le savoir. C'est ce savoir que je cherche à financer pour  garantir aux futurs usagers un produit efficace à la hauteur de l'investissement qu'il vaudra.

Première innovation et premier produit, le système "SAINT AIR", un purificateur d'air technologique et compact destiné aux espaces confinés tels qu'automobiles.

En effet, l'automobile est l'espace qui concentre le plus de pollution comme en témoignent beaucoup d'experts notamment dans le domaine médical et faire en sorte d'avoir le droit de respirer un air sain et de qualité lors de l'utilisation de notre véhicule est le but fixé pour ce système.

L'innovation fait l'objet d'un dépôt de brevet et son fort potentiel pour constituer une solution référence dans le domaine de la qualité de l'air intérieur ont permis d'intéresser le CNRS (Centre National de Recherche Scientifique), dont une équipe participe avec moi au développement,  et de recevoir l'appui de l'ADEME (Agence de Développement de  l'Environnement et de la Maitrise d'Energie) qui finance, en partie, les travaux.

Sachez qu’une mauvaise qualité de l’air entame notre capitale santé sans signe précurseurs, ce qui pousse beaucoup à adopter une attitude d’insouciance face à ce problème de santé publique. Ainsi, constituer un système qui permettrait, tout au long des trajets, d’agir sur la qualité de l’air respiré permettrait à votre véhicule d’acquérir la fonction « bulle protectrice » contre la pollution, vous êtes plus serein, votre trajet est plus agréable et les alertes aux pics de pollution annoncés soit à la radio ou sur les bornes d’informations routières ne vous concerne plus.

Croyant fermement à la nécessité de faire émerger cette innovation, depuis plus d’un an mon savoir-faire et mes compétences sont mobilisés en plus de la quasi-totalité de mes fonds propres ayant permis la création de la société et la continuité du projet à ce jour. Aussi, le traitement de la pollution de l’air reste à ce jour complexe compte tenu des multiples paramètres intervenant dans sa composition et offrir un produit robuste, fiable, à maintenance réduite, informatif, dynamique et avec une garantie d’innocuité exige un effort de R&D impératif l’éloignant des gadgets et autres systèmes ne dépassant pas le stade des revendications.

Les fonds récoltés (objectif de campagne atteint ou non) seront utilisés dans la société MEDINE Technology (http://www.societe.com/societe/medine-technology-805068152.html) d’une part pour permettre de réaliser sa première création d’emploi et d’autres part pour financer l’évolution du produit (en phase prototype actuellement) et l’initiation d’un complément d’études concernant l’élimination des particules fines classées cancérigènes par l’OMS.

Votre contribution est essentielle pour permettre au porteur de projet, que je suis, de soutenir la phase de R&D qui par essence est consommatrice de fonds et ne permet pas, dans les débuts d’une jeune entreprise innovante, de s’autofinancer.

Sur le plan technique et scientifique, le porteur de projet et l'équipe du CNRS sauront atteindre les objectifs d’étapes et feront évoluer le produit. Cependant le défi du financement des travaux reste à relever et cette campagne est un des moyens éthique que l’équipe souhaite utiliser et réussir afin de maximiser les chances d’aller le plus loin possible.

Aussi, il s’agit d’un projet d’innovation qui exige des temps plus ou moins long pour permettre une mise sur le marché responsable (R&D puis industrialisation puis commercialisation), ainsi la prévision de mise sur le marché n’est qu’ en 2018.

Vous ne pouvez pas contribuer pour une raison ou une autre, alors  peut être pourriez-vous aider  en passant le mot……en parler autour de vous. Dans ce cadre vous pouvez utiliser les outils de partage du site Indiegogo.

A titre de référence, il vous est possible de vérifier ma contribution à l’enrichissement du patrimoine inventif des sociétés dans lesquelles j’ai travaillées auparavant (brevets d’inventions).

http://worldwide.espacenet.com/searchResults?ST=singleline&locale=fr_EP&submitted=true&DB=worldwide.espacenet.com&query=Yazid+yaniss+belkouche&Submit=RECHERCHE

Partenaires

CNRS  : http://www.cnrs.fr/ ; ADEME  : http://www.ademe.fr/


Sincères remerciements pour votre attention et éventuelles contributions.

YY.BELKOUCHE

story:
FOOD JUSTICE can only happen with ECONOMIC, RACIAL and CLIMATE JUSTICE!

March Against Monsanto Boston :

Rally for World Food Justice

SAT MAY 23 | March to Copley 1-2p (route tba) & Rally at Copley Sq 2-4p
#MAMBoston #FoodJustice #MAM

Check out our Facebook event page and official website for more information!

On Saturday, May 23, 2015, people from across Massachusetts will come together for Food Justice. Food and health advocates, farmers, small businesses, faith leaders and grassroots organizations will join community members and artists of all genres in a day of learning, sharing and advocacy for Food, Health, Environment & Communities!

For the third year in a row, over 400 cities worldwide, from Seattle to Johannesburg, are organizing local Marches Against Monsanto, and many expect to receive thousands in attendance. Our Boston event is in solidarity with this worldwide movement, and it is the second year we also host the Rally For World Food Justice on the same day. There were 1000 people in attendance at the 2014 March & Rally. Your support will ensure the momentum continues in 2015!


The Boston organizing team is a small ad hoc group of activists from various groups and individuals coming together. We are seeking funding from individual community members through this campaign and sponsorships from local businesses and organizations that align with our working definition of Food Justice (see website).

Locally in Boston, our goal is to incorporate a broad Food Justice mission into this event, highlighting its connection to economic, climate and racial justice and committing to prioritizing and putting front and center the voices and stories of our local communities, specifically those in systemically affected by lack of access, while maintaining an international perspective and solidarity. The Rally will feature teach-ins from community leaders, public speakers from across these movements, as well as local community musicians, artists, and vendors.

Advocates will speak and lead teach-ins about GMO legislation, local access to healthy foods, farming and more! Artists will engage us with dance, music, spoken word and puppetry to make our message accessible and profound!

  • GMO facts, labeling, banning
  • Glyphosate facts and current research
  • Access to Healthy foods for All
  • Supporting organic Farmers
  • Global awareness 
  • Guarding our Seeds and the Bees
  • Our health and wellbeing!

Knowledge for Thought * Art for our Hearts * Joined in Action


What Your Support Will Provide

Bringing together such a wonderful and strong grassroots coalition has modest but very real costs that add up. We need your support to make this day a resounding success!

With $2,000, we will be able to:

  • Print flyers and postcards to heighten visibility and share this event far and wide
  • Offer transportation to food advocates traveling from across our state
  • Supply artists with materials for puppetry, dance and music
  • Fund a Kids & Family table with interactive activities
  • Provide American Sign Language translation
  • Support Street Medics and Legal Observers to keep up healthy and help protect our rights
  • Have a safety net to continue this coalition-building work after this event

What We Will Achieve

Your kind contribution will ensure this event successfully brings together people from various backgrounds for our shared goal of labeling / banning GMOs and Food Justice for all.

Since this is a grassroots effort, the perks of your contribution will be everyone's deep Gratitude and Shout Outs across social media and other internet outlets!

May this effort catalyze a sustained and fruitful collaboration among all of us!


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please Spread the Word! Share with your friends: This campaign page, the Facebook event page, and the official event page at FoodJustice.ActivistCalendar.org
  • Twitter and other Hashtags: #MAMBoston #FoodJustice #MAM #MarchMay23
  • Share your Story! Make a quick and easy phone call to VoJo.co ((888) 821-7563 ext.10552 - after you record, wait for instructions to save) and tell the world Why you are Part of this Movement: Stories will create our own Oral History, serve as Testimonials, and be part of a possible art project.
  • You can also use the Indiegogo share tools below!

What does JUSTICE look like? Come help us VISION a new FUTURE for FOOD

story:
The Naomh Eanna is one of the last riveted ships to be built in the Liffey Dock Yard in Dublin.  The project is to restore the ship and prevent her from being scrapped, The restoration will include a Boutique Hostel on board, wine bar and bistro, a micro brewery and a live museum  and engine room to celebrate the ship's history and those whom it served as the Aran Island ferry from 1956-1988.

We need to raise lots of money about €2 million in total, however we are having issues getting investors on board.  We now feel that we have to do the project in stages...the first stage is to make the ship good and paint her and get her into a condition where people can visit and support the project.

Part of the big plan is a Micro Brewery, so we have decided to work a bit of reverse practice for the project, and start the micro brewery first!

The money raised here will go towards, buying the equipment and set up of the micro brewery and start brewing beer to sell.  All money from beer sales goes to the Naomh Eanna restoration fund.  Hopefully this will show investors and banks that we are actually doing something, and we can start on the full restoration.

We would like to set up our brewery on board initially, but if we cant we have another location, and will move on board as soon as possible.  So the money raised here goes to brewery equipment, licences etc.

The Risks?  Are there any?  I suppose there are!  The ship may never be restored?  If this happens we have a micro brewery business that we will keep running at another location.  The other risk is the micro brewery fails, lets hope this does not happen.

So!  Help support the restoration of an historic ship and support the creation of some jobs and a micro brewery.  Donate now to help!

story:
Following the trend of Marijuana legalization around the globe, Jamaica also plans to “free up” itself. This seems great, however the cards are still stacked against the traditional farmers who stand to lose out on what they have fought for with their blood sweat and tears as big multi-national corporations have high hopes of cashing in on this “Green Gold” rush.    


We are a Nonprofit Organization set up to ensure a place in the regulated cannabis industry for Grassroots People and Rastafari.

 WHGFA’s objectives are to make sure that those who have paid the price – who have been going to jail, going to prison, getting the baton licks, who have been planting the herb only to get it cut down by police and soldiers, and yet have been persistent with this product – that the rights of these individuals are protected. 


Although the concept is simple, we still need some basic infrastructure to make this happen.



We believe that traditional farmers should have the opportunity to step out of years of stigmatization and have the opportunity to grow ganja legally.




"We have a product that is known to be the best in the world, and it is in demand by the world. So why should we continue to watch our people suffer? We don't have any money, but we have a product that can be utilized to bring money into Jamaica to help alleviate the poverty-stricken conditions that the masses of the people live in. We can plant herb and reap herb every day,"

 - Ras Iyah V 



About us

WHGFA is already a leading example of social entrepreneurship for grassroots people and strives to use its success to inspire others in the region demonstrating that social business is the way for true sustainable development.




Farmers, especially in developing countries, can be charged relatively high interest rates by commercial banks, or may be refused credit due to lack of collateral. The Association will also form a credit union to support its members. WHFGA emphasizes the idea of ‘Sustainable Community Development’; focusing on creating rural infrastructure, employment, environmental, social, and economic sustainability and responsibility, through a local supportive agricultural association.


Your Impact

Your contribution will directly make a positive difference in the lives of grassroots ganja farmers and provide families the opportunity to create a sustainable livelihood right on their own doorstep. 


What You Get In Return?

Check out our exciting and exclusive perks ! 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have the funds, but still want to help us out, please share this campaign with friends and family, people that are interested in Ganja, and anyone rooting for Grassroots people.


WHGFA in the Media


Association Launch - http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20140214/lead/lead8.html

Harvard Professor to Address WHGFA http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20140412/western/western2.html

WHGFA Petiton the Prime Minister http://nationwideradiojm.com/westmoreland-hemp-famers-wants-exclusion-from-countrys-ganja-laws/ 

http://www.src.gov.jm/westmoreland-ganja-farmers-petition-prime-minister-for-freedom-to-grow-and-trade-marijuana/

Green Growing: http://jamaicagleaner.com/article/western-focus/20150110/ganja-cultivation-can-reduce-watershed-destruction-say-farmers

Justice Minister Speaks http://jis.gov.jm/justice-minister-urges-citizens-respect-police/

story:
Mike and Hilary Griffiths'  sponsored Trek up Mount Kenya

 We are in Kenya for three months volunteering with a small Kenyan NGO  called Village HopeCore. This organisation provides micro finance and Public Health education and support to communities in Central Kenya near to Mount Kenya.

We are very impressed with the work the organisation does, which includes providing clean drinking water to all 180 schools in the district and combating poverty through providing micro loans to local people, mostly women, along with business education and support and health education. The loans are typically provided to people who are living on less than £70 a month and often results in them increasing their monthly income by around 100%  or more. The stories of loan recipients are inspiring and can be found on the Village HopeCore website:-

http://villagehopecore.org/microfinance-program/success-stories  

This is an example

Mary Nyaga, a member of the Mwende Group, used her microloan to purchase a wood-fired commercial oven and baking trays to start a commercial baking business. Working in a shed adjacent to her home, she bakes and delivers muffins and other bread products to three local markets four days a week. She also makes specialty cakes to order for weddings, birthdays, and other special occasions. Before the microloan, the family’s primary income source was the sale of any farm produce not used in the home. Her husband is the primary caretaker of the farm. With the microloan her household income has doubled as a result of her baking business.

We would like to support the community by raising funds to provide a loan to one HopeCore group of 12 local people.  We hope to raise about £1,000 from the trek towards an overall target of around £4,000 to fully fund a loan cycle (more money always welcome but we have other ideas for raising the balance and won't come back to you for more funds!). The great thing about Village Hopecore is that the money goes on being recycled as one group repays their loan another group can be funded.  £2,700 will go directly to the group in loans and the rest is spent in providing business education and support for planning and health education and support.

We had always planned to climb Mount Kenya while we are here but have now decided to do this as a sponsored event to raise the money. Mount Kenya is the second highest peak in Africa after Mount Kilimanjaro. We will trek from the entrance to the National Park to Point Lenana  which at 4,985 m. is the highest peak of the mountain that can be reached without technical climbing.

We will of course cover all the costs of the trek and all the money raised will go directly to support people living in poverty.

Please support this life changing cause  with any donation you can afford!
story_txt:
Mike and Hilary Griffiths'  sponsored Trek up Mount Kenya

 We are in Kenya for three months volunteering with a small
Kenyan NGO  called Village HopeCore. This organisation provides micro finance and
Public Health education and support to communities in Central Kenya near to
Mount Kenya.
We are very impressed with the work the organisation does,
which includes providing clean drinking water to all 180 schools in the district
and combating poverty through providing micro loans to local people, mostly
women, along with business education and support and health education. The loans are typically provided to people who are living on less than £70 a month and often results in them increasing their monthly income by around 100%  or more. The
stories of loan recipients are inspiring and can be found on the Village
HopeCore website:-
http://villagehopecore.org/microfinance-program/success-stories
 
This is an example

other special occasions. Before the microloan, the family’s primary income
source was the sale of any farm produce not used in the home. Her husband is

story:
Why Aquaponics?
  • 100% USDA organic, non-GMO, and highly nutritious
  • One acre of indoor aquaponic farming produces the same amount of produce as twenty acres of conventional farming
  • Global arable land is decreasing at a staggering rate globally
  • Conventional agriculture uses 70% of freshwater on Earth; unsustainable
  • Aquaponics uses 90% less water than conventional agriculture 
  • 365-day a year growing season
  • Higher yields
  • Shorter growing cycles
  • Fresh fish (high source of protein and Omega 3’s)
  • Viable in dense urban centers and resource scarce economies
  • Farming for the 21st century
What is Aquaponics?
  • A closed-loop system of aquaculture in which the waste produced by farmed fish or other aquatic animals supplies all the essential nutrients for plants grown hydroponically, which in turn purify the water

Why one for one?
  • 49 million Americans don’t know where their next meal is coming from
  • 16 million are children and 5 million senior citizens… need we say any more?
  • Americans should NEVER have to choose between paying the electric bill or putting food on the table
Why open source?
  • It has been unnecessarily DIFFICULT and EXPENSIVE for us to find accurate information in the aquaponics/hydroponics space with regards to construction and operation of a farm
  • We don’t believe anyone should have to go down this route… EVER AGAIN


Why local?
  • Less food miles (less spoilage, lower transportation costs and smaller carbon footprint)
  • Freshness and nutrition is maintained within produce... AKA tastes WAYYY better
  • Closer relationship with our customers and community

Why shipping containers?
  • Cheap and ubiquitous
  • Incredibly efficient to heat/cool
  • Modular, already insulated, extremely sturdy (designed for load capacity of 80,000 lbs), and large enough to grow inside of
  • Easily transported and easy to retrofit
  • Repurposing of materials that would otherwise be tossed in landfill
Why LED lights?
  • Energy efficient (low operational costs)
  • Low heat output
  • Covers the full spectrum of lighting required of plants for optimal growth

How productive is Renaissance Farms?
  • 40,000 lbs of microgreens annually (indoors)... Arugula, watercress, basil, mustard, beets, amaranth, etc.
  • 4,000 lbs of fruiting crops and leafy greens annually (sunlit greenhouses)... Tomatoes, peppers, cucumbers, lettuce, kale, chard, etc.
  • 30,000 lbs of fresh Tilapia annually (indoors)

How does Renaissance Farms sell its produce?
  • Consumers subscribe to our Community Supported Agriculture (CSA) model via monthly fee (think Netflix, but for fresh produce)
  • RF distributes produce via same day delivery service
  • CSA provides local farmer with upfront insurance against any calamity during growing season while providing consumers with the freshest, local, organic produce possible
  • IMPORTANT: If you are interested in signing up for a CSA subscription, please contact us at info@RenaissanceFarmsLLC.com
  • The rest of our offerings will be sold via farmers markets, onsite farm-to-fork dining, and other vertically integrated distribution outlets
Does Renaissance Farms make money?
  • Yes, built from ground up to be 100% economically viable
  • Incredible efficiency in controlled environment agriculture + advancements in growing tech results in elimination of variables (allows us to control risk/reduce chance of crop failure)
  • By selling directly to the consumer, the farmer collects 100% of the profit (please see artistic diagrams below for further explanation)
Conventional Food Supply Chain


Renaissance Farms CSA Food Supply Chain


What do we need the money for?
  • 12 insulated shipping containers
  • Fish tanks
  • Grow racks
  • Growing supplies
  • LED Lights
  • Environmental control equipment
  • Sunlit greenhouses
  • Solar panels and windmills
  • Rainwater storage tanks
  • Construction and engineering costs

Why renewable energy?
  • The world has a choice: we can either live in the 19th century or the 21st century; we choose the latter (duh!)
Will we face challenges?
  • Yes, of course! … As did every other entrepreneur who ventured out into the great unknown with the goal of changing the world
  • We are confident in our ability to adapt and overcome any challenges that stand in our way (bring it on!
  • "The best of the gold is at the bottom of the barrels of crap." - Randy Pausch (Although in this case, fish tanks filled with fish poop!)
What prizes are available?
  • $100, $1000, $5000 or $10000 -  Donate 4 lbs, 40 lbs, 200 lbs or 400 lbs of Produce: We will donate our Renaissance Farms aquaponic microgreens to the Capital Area Food Bank of Austin, TX. These highly nutritious, USDA organic (did we mention super tasty??) microgreens will be harvested and delivered same day to the Food Bank, where they will be available for immediate pickup and consumption!

  • $200 - Grand Opening Celebration: You will receive one Golden Ticket to the grand opening night celebration of Renaissance Farms. The evening festivities will be fully catered, including food prepared with RF produce by local celebrity chefs, drinks supplied by local craft breweries, and live music performed by the finest local Austin musicians and late night DJ's. Trust us... This will be one party you won't want to miss.


  • $200 - Name in RF Branding Artwork: The cornerstone of the Renaissance Farms campaign... We will custom design our badass product packaging artwork to include your name. As Renaissance Farms expands and battles hunger across the United States, you will be right there with us and your name will stay on every product we sell – forever. This stylish artwork will be applied to produce packaging, cold-pressed juice bottles, CSA boxes, and any other future products we sell. 



  • $100 - Engraved RF Brick: We will engrave your name on a brick that will help form the pavilion area of Renaissance Farms. This area will serve as the cultural epicenter of our farm, a gathering area for social events, educational workshops, and outdoor dining. Each brick will serve as a timeless reminder to all visitors that this project would not have been feasible without your help. We will send you a one-of-a-kind certificate documenting your contribution to fighting world hunger as a token of our gratitude.


  • $75 - RF T-Shirt: One EXTRA BALLIN' super soft cotton crew neck T-shirt that you can wear for the rest of your life because it will never go out of style. When you wear this shirt, everyone will know your thumb is green and your style is fresh! Yeah, it'll change your life... all the more reason to buy two!


  • $50 - Limited Edition Shopping Bag: We will send you a gnarly limited edition reusable Renaissance Farms shopping bag. There are a lot of reusable shopping bags out there, but this bag will be by far the most rad of them all. Why you may ask? Because it's made of 100% biodegradable jute. Take that, landfill!


  • $25 - Wristband + Social Media Shoutout: We will send you a super dope Renaissance Farms wristband for you to wear and show off to your friends, thereby letting everyone know that you are a part of the generation that took a firm stand against hunger and poverty. We will also feature a personalized shout out on our social media pages, thus etching you into digital history forever!


Are Andy and Sulaman qualified to be successful farmers?
  • Nearly 8 years of aquaponics/hydroponics experience between the two of us
  • Constructed 4 small scale growing systems of our own (NFT, media bed, vertical channel, and raft)
  • 130 page business plan
  • Extensive backgrounds in economics, business operations, and finance 
  • Both HIGHLY competitive with WILD imaginations



How does Renaissance Farms impact 1 billion people?
  • Growing the highest quality produce starting in Austin, TX, and then scaling across the United States and worldwide
  • Open sourcing our intellectual property means anyone with an Internet connection can build Renaissance Farms for themselves at our cost anywhere in the world
  • Ushering in the next green revolution via 21st century growing methods and technology, resulting in an unprecedented era of worldwide food security for all, regardless of social status
  • Transparency and full disclosure are core principles on which RF was founded; these principles are the means by which we will give YOU the power to change the world
Aren't you afraid competitors will take advantage of your ideas and put you out of business?
  • No! In fact, we encourage as many people as possible to replicate and improve upon this idea globally
  • Patents stifle innovation and create artificial scarcity where there should be none
  • Renaissance Farms is not in the business of competition; we are in the business of changing lives 
  • "When I think about creating abundance, it's not about creating a life of luxury for everybody on this planet; it's about creating a life of possibility. It is about taking that which was scarce and making it abundant." - Peter Diamandis
What if Renaissance Farms blows past its fundraising goal?
  • Um, yeah, that would be amazing!
  • We would take 100% of the surplus and simply add more growing space (shipping containers)... sooo, more fresh nutritious produce for everyone
Who are Andy and Sulaman?
  • Two lifelong friends with a passion for healthy living, impact entrepreneurship, and living life to the fullest


Nothing is more powerful than an idea whose time has come - Renaissance Farms is the future of 21st century social enterprise.

If all goes to plan, Renaissance Farms will be fully operational by Winter 2015.

The single best way you can help Renaissance Farms is to share our story with the world through social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Tumblr, Reddit, Youtube, Linkedin, and Pinterest.

Renaissance Farms is farming by the people, for the people. Your support is vital to our success. Help us change the world and create a brighter future for generations to come.

Sincerely,

Andy Cole & Sulaman Chaudhry, Co-Founders

This project would not have been possible without help from the following people: Juan Restrepo (Facility Design), Robert Lopez and Yvonne Guerra (Raging Bull Productions - Film and Editing), Kurt Von Weisenstein (Film), Rakhee Yadav (Oxy Works - Logo and Artwork), Nicolas Thaddeus Wachter (Film),  Paul Michael Saldana (Film), Ernest Brown (Business Consultant), Hank Perret (CEO of Capital Area Food Bank), Paul Gaither (Marketing & Communications Director CAFB), and everyone at the Capital Area Food Bank of Texas.

story:
What's Going On?

The villages of Court Gada and Rombhila are home to some of the most economically and socially marginalized peoples in Odisha, one of the most deprived regions of India. Without any access to water or sanitation, they have been condemned to a life of depravity and neglect. What’s worse, with historic droughts threatening the livelihoods of their subsistence farming lifestyle that had already kept them below the poverty line, the prospects for change are nearly non-existent.

However, Asepsis, with the help of our amazing grassroots partner organization ASHA (Association for Sanitation and Health Activities), are working to change that. Enlisting members of the community to build 231 toilets for 231 families, while providing life-saving training and awareness program, Asepsis and ASHA will ensure that no child in Court Gada or Rombhila miss school because of an easily preventable waterborne illness; that no women or girls are sexually assaulted in search of a place to go to the bathroom; and that no child dies because we did not do anything to help.
Please join us!

What YOU can do:

  1. Join our fundraising campaign. Rally your friends and family to help provide 231 toilets for 231 families in Odisha, India. It's only $250 to give a family safe, dignified access to sanitation 
  2. Join our sister photography campaign: the #ComingClean Challenge. The winner will be coming with us to help re-define the sanitation crisis and uncover it as the social injustice we know it to be. 

Who are we?

Asepsis is a non-profit collaborative redefining the way we look at the sanitation crisis and the way that we solve it. Incorporating fundraising initiatives and awareness campaigns into community-based implementation projects around the world, we utilize a multi-faceted approach to address some of the most pressing issues in sanitation. We are starting a new dialogue on a historically neglected issue through the mediums of photography, journalism, and digital media to inform and activate people from all walks of life towards a common mission.



Why Us?

Because we’re doing it differently. In both the way we chose our partners and carry out awareness campaign we put people first, aiming to do what's best for the community and how to best address the issue. 

Partnership Structure

We believe that in many places the issue is not that a product is not available to help the community, but moreover that the distribution and community awareness portion is lacking. We search for organizations that understand the importance of taking a community-led sanitation approach and aim to increase their capacity, helping to build the toilets while they work on the unbelievably important community awareness aspect of the project. 

Awareness

We realize that the issue of the sanitation crisis cannot be solved simply with the construction of toilets. We need to change the way we think about and interact with it. What we need is for the story of this social injustice to be told. We cannot keep it in the shadows any longer. For change to happen, we must start #ComingClean! 


Over the next two months, during our crowdfunding effort, we are searching for photographers from around the country -- students, professionals, or freelancers -- to submit their best work highlighting a social injustice to have the opportunity of a lifetime through the Asepsis #ComingClean Challenge. The winner of the competition -- as decided by our award-winning panel of judges -- will have the opportunity for an all-expenses paid trip to Odisha, India with the members of the Asepsis team to document the work that we are doing in India and tell the story of the sanitation crisis through photography, helping to bring this hidden epidemic to light.

For more information on how to get involved with the #ComingClean Challenge, visit our website at: http://www.asepsis.org/


The Project

From November 19th to December 31st, we are raising funds to construct 231 toilets for 231 families in Odisha, India. The large scale of this project will help make two villages free of open defecation. Working with our on-the-ground partner, ASHA (Association for Sanitation and Health Activities), we will cooperate with the community to improve sanitation through comprehensive and inclusive training programs that ensure long-term success.

ASHA has a great reputation with local leaders, government officials, and families in the area they work; most of their staff coming from Odisha. They ensure the path to improved sanitation does not stop with the construction of a toilet, but additionally work to promote open dialogue on the health and socioeconomic benefits of these toilets. ASHA also hires local residents of the communities to build the toilets themselves and pay them a good wage by local standards. All of this is the reason that ASHA has become known as a well-respected and extremely effective organization in the promotion of sanitation throughout the area, reducing the dependency of villages on the government and helping them promote their own sanitation solutions. 

Once the funds are raised and the toilets are constructed, Asepsis will be traveling to these villages to meet with members of the community and ensure that the changes we are making are lasting and for the better.

Picture taken after meeting ASHA, Asepsis, and Gram Panchayat meeting. From left to right: Maz Obuz (Asepsis), Evan Young (Asepsis), Dipty Ranjan Sahoo (ASHA, Treasurer), Tuna Rout (ASHA, Secretary), RajSunakhala Panchayat Leader, Sandeep Bara (ASHA, President)


Break-down of the $250 

$200 will be going directly towards building the toilets. This will cover the material costs of the toilet and labor. It takes each "toilet team" about 1 week to create a finished toilet for a family.

$50 will be going towards verification, monitoring and evaluation of the project via the #ComingClean Challenge.  Our photojournalist winner of the Challenge will be coming to document the work we are doing in the community and delving into the crisis, aiming to best understand the intricacies of the area and making sure that we are indeed making the best possible impact in the community. Toilets are only the first step. From a development standpoint, while community programs ensure short- term adoption we need to make sure that this will in fact have a long lasting impact.  Every project that Asepsis carries out will have a visual-heavy monitoring and evaluation component in order to create the greatest amount of transparency for our supporters. 


More Information About the Community

The two villages we will be working in are Court Gada and Rombhabila. They both come under RajSunakhala Panchayat of Ranapur block in Nayagarh District and are surrounded by small mountains 17 K.M away from Nayagarh District town, Odisha.

There are currently more than 470 households with a total population of 2600 in Court Gada and Rombhabila village, out of which 1100 in Court Gada and 1500 in Rombhabila. The majority of the people in Court Gada and Rombhabila villages belong to Scheduled Caste (SC) and Scheduled Tribe (ST) and are economically marginalized. These were formerly known as “untouchables.”

The baseline survey carried out by “ASHA” and “DWSM” revealed that out of 183 households 181 households have no access to toilets, hence, 99% of the population of Court Gada defecates in the open. In Rombhabila village, more than 78% of the population has no access to toilets.

The Project (Continued)

This project will work towards the creation of two open defecation-free environments in Court Gada and Rombhabila, dramatically reducing the amount of diseases associated with sanitation problems. 

The Toilet Team

ASHA pays its workers -- residents of the local community -- about $10 per day. This is above the local average and is justified by the training and workshops they provide for their workers. This training covers the technical aspects of construction and maintenance, along with the health benefits provided by the toilets, solidifying an understanding of the link between sanitation and health. These teams of workers are called the “Toilet Team.”

Maintenance

Maintenance of each toilet will be the responsibility of the concerned beneficiary; however, ASHA will request assistance from the local health department of Sunakhala and their health expert Dr. Sanjaya Mohanty to carry out inspections. ASHA will also provide follow-up checks, advice and expertise

Please Join us as we aim to make a positive impact in this community and begin to redefine the sanitation crisis worldwide.

Thank you!

What's Going On?
The villages of Court Gada and Rombhila are home to some of the most economically and socially marginalized peoples in Odisha, one of the most deprived regions of India. Without any access to water or sanitation, they have been condemned to a life of depravity and neglect. What’s worse, with historic droughts threatening the livelihoods of their subsistence farming lifestyle that had already kept them below the poverty line, the prospects for change are nearly non-existent.

However, Asepsis, with the help of our amazing grassroots partner organization ASHA (Association for Sanitation and Health Activities), are working to change that. Enlisting members of the community to build 231 toilets for 231 families, while providing life-saving training and awareness program, Asepsis and ASHA will ensure that no child in Court Gada or Rombhila miss school because of an easily preventable waterborne illness; that no women or girls are sexually assaulted in search of a place to go to the bathroom; and that no child dies because we did not do anything to help.

Please join us!



What YOU can do:

Join our fundraising campaign. Rally your friends and family to help provide 231 toilets for 231 families in Odisha, India. It's only $250 to give a family safe, dignified access to sanitation 
Join our sister photography campaign: the #ComingClean Challenge. The winner will be coming with us to help re-define the sanitation crisis and uncover it as the social injustice we know it to be. 


Who are we?
Asepsis is a non-profit collaborative redefining the way we look at the sanitation crisis and the way that we solve it. Incorporating fundraising initiatives and awareness campaigns into community-based implementation projects around the world, we utilize a multi-faceted approach to address some of the most pressing issues in sanitation. We are starting a new dialogue on a historically neglected issue through the mediums of photography, journalism, and digital media to inform and activate people from all walks of life towards a common mission.









Why Us?
Because we’re doing it differently. In both the way we chose our partners and carry out awareness campaign we put people first, aiming to do what's best for the community and how to best address the issue. 

Partnership Structure

We believe that in many places the issue is not that a product is not available to help the community, but moreover that the distribution and community awareness portion is lacking. We search for organizations that understand the importance of taking a community-led sanitation approach and aim to increase their capacity, helping to build the toilets while they work on the unbelievably important community awareness aspect of the project. 
Awareness

We realize that the issue of the sanitation crisis cannot be solved simply with the construction of toilets. We need to change the way we think about and interact with it. What we need is for the story of this social injustice to be told. We cannot keep it in the shadows any longer. For change to happen, we must start #ComingClean! 


Over the next two months, during our crowdfunding effort, we are searching for photographers from around the country -- students, professionals, or freelancers -- to submit their best work highlighting a social injustice to have the opportunity of a lifetime through the Asepsis #ComingClean Challenge. The winner of the competition -- as decided by our award-winning panel of judges -- will have the opportunity for an all-expenses paid trip to Odisha, India with the members of the Asepsis team to document the work that we are doing in India and tell the story of the sanitation crisis through photography, helping to bring this hidden epidemic to light.
For more information on how to get involved with the #ComingClean Challenge, visit our website at: http://www.asepsis.org/


The Project

From November 19th to December 31st, we are raising funds to construct 231 toilets for 231 families in Odisha, India. The large scale of this project will help make two villages free of open defecation. Working with our on-the-ground partner, ASHA (Association for Sanitation and Health Activities), we will cooperate with the community to improve sanitation through comprehensive and inclusive training programs that ensure long-term success.


ASHA has a great reputation with local leaders, government officials, and families in the area they work; most of their staff coming from Odisha. They ensure the path to improved sanitation does not stop with the construction of a toilet, but additionally work to promote open dialogue on the health and socioeconomic benefits of these toilets. ASHA also hires local residents of the communities to build the toilets themselves and pay them a good wage by local standards. All of this is the reason that ASHA has become known as a well-respected and extremely effective organization in the promotion of sanitation throughout the area, reducing the dependency of villages on the government and helping them promote their own sanitation solutions. 

Once the funds are raised and the toilets are constructed, Asepsis will be traveling to these villages to meet with members of the community and ensure that the changes we are making are lasting and for the better.




Picture taken after meeting ASHA, Asepsis, and Gram Panchayat meeting. From left to right: Maz Obuz (Asepsis), Evan Young (Asepsis), Dipty Ranjan Sahoo (ASHA, Treasurer), Tuna Rout (ASHA, Secretary), RajSunakhala Panchayat Leader, Sandeep Bara (ASHA, President)



Break-down of the $250 

$200 will be going directly towards building the toilets. This will cover the material costs of the toilet and labor. It takes each "toilet team" about 1 week to create a finished toilet for a family.
$50 will be going towards verification, monitoring and evaluation of the project via the #ComingClean Challenge.  Our photojournalist winner of the Challenge will be coming to document the work we are doing in the community and delving into the crisis, aiming to best understand the intricacies of the area and making sure that we are indeed making the best possible impact in the community. Toilets are only the first step. From a development standpoint, while community programs ensure short- term adoption we need to make sure that this will in fact have a long lasting impact.  Every project that Asepsis carries out will have a visual-heavy monitoring and evaluation component in order to create the greatest amount of transparency for our supporters. 

More Information About the Community
The two villages we will be working in are Court Gada and Rombhabila. They both come under RajSunakhala Panchayat of Ranapur block in Nayagarh District and are surrounded by small mountains 17 K.M away from Nayagarh District town, Odisha.




There are currently more than 470 households with a total population of 2600 in Court Gada and Rombhabila village, out of which 1100 in Court Gada and 1500 in Rombhabila. The majority of the people in Court Gada and Rombhabila villages belong to Scheduled Caste (SC) and Scheduled Tribe (ST) and are economically marginalized. These were formerly known as “untouchables.”
The baseline survey carried out by “ASHA” and “DWSM” revealed that out of 183 households 181 households have no access to toilets, hence, 99% of the population of Court Gada defecates in the open. In Rombhabila village, more than 78% of the population has no access to toilets.




The Project (Continued)
This project will work towards the creation of two open defecation-free environments in Court Gada and Rombhabila, dramatically reducing the amount of diseases associated with sanitation problems. 
The Toilet Team
ASHA pays its workers -- residents of the local community -- about $10 per day. This is above the local average and is justified by the training and workshops they provide for their workers. This training covers the technical aspects of construction and maintenance, along with the health benefits provided by the toilets, solidifying an understanding of the link between sanitation and health. These teams of workers are called the “Toilet Team.”
Maintenance 
Maintenance of each toilet will be the responsibility of the concerned beneficiary; however, ASHA will request assistance from the local health department of Sunakhala and their health expert Dr. Sanjaya Mohanty to carry out inspections. ASHA will also provide follow-up checks, advice and expertise
Please Join us as we aim to make a positive impact in this community and begin to redefine the sanitation crisis worldwide.
Thank you!

story:
OUR STORY... 

Watauga County has astounding levels of food insecurity: 24.2% of children live in food-insecure homes and only 11% of qualified children get free or reduced meals during the summer months. A unique program to address these issues is the cost share program of High Country CSA (HCCSA), which offers 36 low-income families a reduced priced box of fresh produce that can be paid for with SNAP-EBT. Though the HCCSA cost-share program has had high participation, the retention rates for this program significantly decrease over the course of the 20-week harvest season, largely due to lack of cooking skills and recipe ideas. We have a unique project to address this issue, but additional funding fell through and we need your help to make it successful.

WHAT WE WANT TO DO...

Cooking for Community

The Cooking for Community Program is a multi-faceted approach to addressing the issue of retention in healthy eating programs available to food-insecure families. This six-week cooking course is open to 30 low-income families participating in the cost-share program during peak season. This innovative program will be evaluated and improved upon in order to be replicated in future years.

Providing...

  • Classes focused on basic cooking skills

  • Budget friendly cooking techniques and recipes

  • Child care that includes hands-on nutritional education for children

  • A free, healthy, fresh meal for the entire family

  • Community growth and development

  • A set of 60 seasonal recipes focused on the fresh produce of the High Country region

Our organization had secured a research grant to support aspects of this work not included in other grants, however, we were recently notified that their funding source had run out and we need your help!

WHAT WE NEED... 

FOOD PRODUCTS

This indigogo funding would provide the $650 needed to purchase non-perishable and perishable local foods for the classes. The foods are key to the demonstration process and will provide a full meal to the low-income participants in the classes and their children.

INTERN STIPEND

The classes will be implemented and examined for a research project by a senior nutrition major from Appalachian State University. This modest $500 stipend is for over 400 hours of work on the project. This is the nutrition intern's second internship with the organization.

ADDITIONAL NEEDS

In addition to food products and an intern stipend, our indigogo campaign will cover costs associated with running kids activities, printing, and the often-overlooked indigogo fee.

WHY WE WILL BE SUCCESSFUL...

Our community partner, Blue Ridge Women in Agriculture (BRWIA) will be implementing the cooking program. BRWIA is dedicated to strengthening the High Country's local food system by supporting women and their families with resources, education, and skills related to sustainable food and agriculture.

  • BRWIA provides cooking demos at the farmers' market throughout the growing season 

  • BRWIA's HomeGrown Workshop Series features local food cooking workshops

  • The classes have guidance from Appalachian State nutrition professors and students

  • We already have 72% of funds secured and we are confident the classes will occur

While we address the needs of all consumers and producers in the High Country, we target women's contributions and needs. We believe that by providing women and their families with opportunities to advance toward agricultural sustainability, improve their economic status and health outcomes, and battle social inequalities, we will support the development of an economically, environmentally, and socially sustainable food system in the High Country.

Cooking for community has the potential to be another successful program. The nutrition and cooking skill curriculum, the low-cost recipe set, and extensive evaluation will provide a model for replicable programs throughout the community. These activities will empower community members to commit to consuming more local, nutritious food.

RISKS & CHALLENGES... 

This cooking program will be repeated yearly with the HCCSA and the curriculum will be shared and used with three other community partners for courses that range from two to four weeks, once a year for the next three years. Our hope is that each year the cooking classes will grow in both success and in evidence-based knowledge for working within this community.

This year the Cooking for Community project will have a research component under advisement from faculty at Appalachian State University. The insight that is gained from this first year will be used to ensure success for the future of this project and in other community programs like it.

**Cauliflower & Hands; Harvesting Kale Photos by Alistair Burke. Courtesy of Heifer Project International

story:
Hi There! 

First of all, thanks a lot for checking our Campaign. If you are into a fresh cup of specialty coffee with a story, and do like the idea of helping significantly in setting up this small Coffee Brand, you are at the right place indeed! 

Our story is simple. We started our quest to Magic beans five months ago, in the Archipel of Indonesian Islands. Islandhopping ourselves to a selection of the great coffee regions, we visited Coffee farms, skipping the middleman and getting great cultural insights in both domestic and Coffeefarmer specific Culture. Today, 5 Months after we hopped on the first ferry towards our first beans, we may proudly state we have a team of three very devoted Caffeinated freaks that, with the very limited budget we have, has the following progress accomplished; 

• We set up a valueable network of coffee farmers, local experts, shop owners and B2B clients. 

• We have selected, negociated and ordered a collection of 4  truly distinct specialty coffees good for 1250 kg green beans of what we believe to be Indonesia's finest Arabica Coffee, ready to be roasted.  

• We have 10 buying partners and taste ambassadors, whom are in line with our inherent values. 

• We have our own website up running, guiding people through the whole story, processes, methods and journey. From farmer to cup.       


• We designed and ordered our packaging, 2500 Exclusive Paper Tubes, which took us nearly 6 months to design. Arrival planned by Mid August. Prototype samples already produced.      

              


Our Journey 

      

    

     




We went Far & beyond. What We still need: 

We made the bean selection, we have our first buyers, we got the coffee here safely, and we have our online platforms up and running - all of this on our own -with the exception of the artworks which were done by a young graphic design student with whom we established a close cooperation. We have spent every dime we could spend, saving money on everything we could do ourselves, and yet it has not been enough. There’s much left to be done and we can only go on with your help. We  With that extra dollar, euro, sterling, rupiah, even Old Obol coins, whatever have you, anything is more than welcome to back us up through these last highly important costs of our dear coffee project, namely; 

• The legal business setup in Indonesia ( 7690 Usd ) 

• The roasting costs of our first batch of 1250 kg of coffee ( 3445 Usd ) 

• Alternative Packages for alternative markets, 2500 krafpaper bags with valve ( 330 Usd ) 

•The Sealing Stickers and Package information stickers ( 115 Usd ) 

Challenges 

Setting up any kind of business in a different country is a big challenge. Many of the remaining costs, big and small, came unexpectedly, popping up out of the blue to present us with yet another major challenge, next to the intercultural web itself. Indonesia's business practices are often different, rules and grey zones sometimes tantalizing. Problems such as ownership, vague foreign investment policy and so on, make us very alert on how challenging it tends to get, therefore encouraging us to be as creative and open as possible with our approaches toward  local business partners. With your financial help, issues like working permits, foreign investment protection, and in general business security, can be dealt with, allowing us to get back on track and make Tales of Coffee happen in the very near future .. 

A long way to Crowdfunding 

It’s never easy to have to ask for financial help but we are doing our very best to be as transparent as possible about every phase of our brand's operation process. Reaching out to the wider community also means we get the chance to raise besides money also awareness on our brand, our goals, and to enhance and guide people through the rich culture, craftmanship, and people behind one of the most renomated coffee beans in the world. We hope to be able to do this, not just through media, but in real life as well - by Organizing coffee tours in coöperation with the farmers and guides on the spot. We sincerely hope to have your ( financial and moral ) support to set up this Coffee Project and that you will Spread the Tale & Join our Journey through Indie Gogo, our website, facebook, instagram or  Pinterest. 

Thank You! 

If you’d like more information, feel free to visit our website www.talesofcoffee.com or contact us through info@talesofcoffee.com or 003222525635! Also, find a brief elaboration on our mission already at the bottom of this very own campaign. We are really looking forward to hearing your stories, questions, proposals, comments, or any feedback at all, and we care to answer you the same day.   

Thank you! 

Tales Of Coffee Team 




>

>

>

>

>

>

>




Our Missions 

( 1 ) Gathering and distributing Indonesia's finest and most Exclusive Single Origin Specialty Coffee 

( 2 ) Creating more awareness among the local farmers and domestic population on the great potential their Natural Resources harbor in them. 

( 3 ) Briefing our buyers on the rich culture behind each and every grain of coffee we serve.  

( 1 ) Our First Trademark: Fine & Exclusive Indonesian Arabica. No Middleman. The Whole Story, freshly roasted. 

We didn't went deliberately for the smaller exclusive farms, it's just that the best coffee tends to be limited in supply because often more vulnerable for diseases and other external threats, and harder to reach, in general. setting sail to Islands and regions where we already knew of they had some World Class coffees, upon arrival e always went one step further by checking with the local coffee communities and experts ( with sometimes a very advanced coffee scene ) which one of the great coffees is the greatest. Depending on variety, altitude, succes of the year's harvest, wash process, bean selection for improved cleanliness, et cetera, a distinction within that World Class specialty region can still be made between great coffees and superior coffees. That is where we try to make the difference to begin with, doing the search ourselves. To welcome people and farmers on our way - that cary great knowledge of the local beans - support us in our search, is of big added value as well. 

Another thing we strive to be top of the nodge in is roasting the beans to their full flavour potential, and this as fresh as possible. Depending on the flavours you could possibly extract out of a certain type, you may want to roast the coffee from a light to medium roast, all the way to a dark french or italian roast. Finding the right balance between the hidden complexity in our coffee beans and the sweeter aroma that comes to play when using a darker roast, is what it's all about. Finest Coffee selection, Fresh roasting & Aroma Conservation from harvest to cup, guarantee a coffee of superawesomedelicious quality.  

(2) Awareness Domestic Coffee Culture 

Our second mission, to educate the local groups on how valuable their own natural resources really are, sprung out of the experience that most of the local people do not fancy too much about their own Origin Coffees and very often, with almost no exceptions, have no knowledge of what types of Coffee Indonesia stores and do not recognize the potential of their coffee towards western markets. With nearly 71 % of the good quality coffee - cultivated locally - leaving the country yearly, the locals often are not aware nor given the opportunity to enjoy the full potential of their Arabica coffee beans. 

We ought to boost initiatives and knowledge surrounding Indonesian Specialty Coffee by several distinct ways; 

* We organize Coffeetours on two of the Islands to let both domestic and visiting audience experience first hand where coffee originates from, which strong cultural traditions are still surrounding the cultivation and what kind of diversity the Indonesian Coffee Scene really has to offer. 

* We ought to work with local people from outside the coffee business as well, indirectly sensitizing them about the richness of their own natural resources. 

( 3 ) Farmer Culture & Indonesian Roots 

Our thirth Mission is a clear one. We want to tell the Tale behind the coffee. Be it the contemporary Tale of Origin, describing what Indonesian Farmers go through on a daily base, or be it the centuries old Tales outlining the Journey Coffee made to arrive all the way from Ethiopia to Indonesia. On our Website www.talesofcoffee.com we guide you through the processes, the craftmanship, the regions and the general Coffee background, supported by field pictures of our Travels on the spot. 

While keeping the cultural values and those beautiful Tales of Coffee as intact as possible, we invest in the farms to compliment old and authentic techniques of bean selection, bean processing, packaging et cetera, adding  several newer approaches to these processes, which in the long run will result in bigger capacity and more financial means for the farmers and their villages. Old Crafts, a pride in craftsmanship, cultivation as an every day legacy to their ancestors, these are things we commit to map, to spread and to guard because those valuess underlie the true beauty of their work.

story:
On July 27th, 2005, the Gateway Center opened its doors for the first time, revolutionizing the way our city approaches the issue of homelessness forever. Over the last 10 years GWC has helped thousands of individuals change their lives and move out of homelessness. Now, you can help make sure our doors remain open for years to come.


What We Do

The Gateway Center works to end homelessness, and particularly chronic homelessness, by providing a supportive and compassionate setting where individuals can receive the tools, therapeutic programs, and services they need to end their homelessness and achieve self-sufficiency.

1. Equip - GWC strives to equip each individual who walks through our doors with tools to restore dignity and end their homelessness. Our first floor operates 24/7 and provides for individuals' most fundamental needs. Services include public showers, restrooms, laundry machines, hygiene kits, phones, a clothing closet, locker storage, and much more. Some people like to say that they 'don't believe in hand outs, but give hand-ups instead'. . . Which is great, but we also agree with Martin Luther King Jr. when he asked how one could expect a person "to pull themselves up by their bootstraps, when they don't have any boots?" 

2. Empower - Gateway Center has 8 residential programs on-site for men working to end their homelessness. Because there is no one-size-fits-all solution to homelessness, each of our programs addresses a different area that may be contributing to a person's homelessness. We have individualized programs for veterans, addiction recovery, mental health, employment training ... Etc.

3. Engage - Gateway connects clients with partner organizations both on-site and in the larger community for long term success. We were founded in a unique spirit of collaboration, and thus do our best to create a "one stop shop" for individuals to access resources and information from our partners. In our building alone, there are offices operated by the Department of Labor, Traveler's Aid, DFACS (Snap/Food Stamps), Mercy Care Clinic, and more.

We Need Your Help

In order to provide these essential resources for our clients, we rely entirely on outside support. We know these fundraising campaigns can be exhausting and perhaps even seem a little arbitrary at times, but the reality is that we wouldn’t be here without them. Your donation makes a HUGE difference!

  • $5 provides a hygiene kit for a client
  • $10 provides meals & food services for a client for one day
  • $15 provides a 7-day MARTA pass
  • $65 fills the tank of our outreach bus
  • $135 provides one day of intensive case management for 18 clients
Can you imagine the monthly water bill for a building with over 100 toilets? (Not to mention heating, cooling, and maintenance!) Without Gateway’s building and our staff who work tirelessly for our clients 24/7, there would be no Gateway Center!

Spread the Word

We hope you'll help us make some noise by sharing with your friends and generating some social media buzz.

  • Share this important campaign via Facebook, Email and Twitter!
  • Remember to use the hashtags #10for10 and #changedlives in your posts!

That's all there is to it, folks!

Together, we can ensure that GWC continues the important work of changing lives and ending homelessness for years to come!

story:
William Marie Wines strives to become a boutique wine label, crafting wines from grapes grown in the Pacific Northwest regions of Oregon and Washington. Sourcing fruit from quality, sustainably managed vineyards farming to the highest environmental standards. 

Edward William and Monique Marie Lefferts, a husband and wife team relocated from Scottsdale Arizona to Portland Oregon with a dream of one day operating a small winery, employing themselves together, and working side by side to achieve a dream in William Marie Wines.

With backgrounds in hospitality, and Ed a Certified Sommelier, both Ed and Mo have gained a true passion for food and wine, and strive to craft the highest quality wine the Pacific Northwest vineyards have to offer. Our campaign to achieve this dream follows years of hard work and effort, which began with our inaugural vintage in 2014, with a Washington syrah sourced from a single vineyard in the Walla Walla Valley. That syrah has been resting in barrel for 5 months, and flavors from initial tastings are all pointing to an exceptional wine, one that they couldn’t be more proud of as first time winemakers. However, to continue in 2015, they need financial assistance to fully realize this dream. The groundwork has been laid by having already solidified contracts both to source the 2015 fruit, and handcraft the wine in a custom crush facility in the heart of Oregon's Willamette Valley. 

Funding this campaign, has more importance than simply making this years harvest into the best juice possible. It helps the two in an instrumental step toward entering the professional winemaking world, with a long-term goal of employing each other together, building a career from a passion, and the continued opportunity to build further relationships in the wine community to grow and sustain.  

Contributions for this campaign will help fund a magnitude of needs to get William Marie Wines off the ground. With two very key contacts already in place, the need for license's and permits to operate, and distribute wine is the starting point. These necessary applications for permits are both with the Oregon Liquor Control Commission and the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau. Your contribution will then assist in funding the costs associated with winemaking from acquisition of grapes, to the crush, barrel purchase and aging, and eventually bottling, corking, and labeling the final product.

Your contribution to William Marie Wines will help fund the following expenses: 

Licensing and Permits: $1,000

2 tons of fruit: $3,200/ton = $6,400

Custom Crush Facility rate: $1,800 /ton = $3,600

More barrels, Bottles, Labels, Corks, Fermenter: $3,000

Total: $14,000

So, they ask that you join them on the journey of taking William Marie Wines from a concept to a reality, by helping create these exceptional boutique wines. They plan to keep contributors fully informed throughout the winemaking process.  Through direct and social media postings you will have an opportunity to follow in the journey of crafting wines from the grapes you’ve helped them acquire and process.

story:
Where it all began (aka who to blame)

Rebel's Kitchen grew out of a youth spent in the kitchens of my mom and her sisters. I know why wooden spoons are important. I appreciate the chemistry of sugar. And I can pull a window pane that will bring a tear. I started Rebel's Kitchen by baking for a weekly Farmer's Market and it has been a labor of love, a labor in which an epidural is seemingly absent and my birthing coach went for a latte. A labor that started with a pile of black sesame seeds and some pandan essence and a Google search. 

My long-term goal for Rebel's Kitchen is for it to be a coffee shop...attached to a my tiny hotel...in a beach town...with a small collection of classic cars to loan to guests. A business that would function as the place you long to visit, a place that will remember you like almond milk in your Costa Rican coffee and prefer a press over drip.

BUT my short-term goal puts Rebel's Kitchen on wheels, in a customized bus from Morbid Rodz; roaming the streets of DC and the festivals of the DelMarVa looking for the undercaffeinated and the underwhelmed, so I can make you overjoyed and buzzing for more.

There's a community component to this project, as well.  I am committed to creating a business that benefits the community as a whole, whether that's providing incredible food and coffee to customers, working with local organizations to help with training and job assistance or donating any remaining food to local charities.  The pay-it-forward lunch program that was planned for the cafe will be slightly altered to become more food-truck friendly but it will still be implemented.

We can't do this alone.  The Ginger and I need you.  We've got about half of what we need for the bus build-out and the equipment.  I thought about selling my dog but he knows too much.  So we need you.  Badly. 

The need, the feed - all guaranteed!

The food truck itself is a custom-built rat rod bus on a new Chevy SUV frame.  So, like me, it's snazzy on the outside and reliable on the inside.  

Your contribution will help fund the bus build, the equipment inside, license and permit fees and all the stuff I've probably not yet realized I will need yet.

Why I put curry in cookies and peppercorns in jam

For as long as I can remember, I've never followed the path of least resistance. Who wants a chocolate chip cookie made with *just* chocolate chips when you can throw in soy sauce and black sesame seeds? Shouldn't croissants be pretzelfied, pop tarts be filled with leeks and goat cheese and Lamingtons made outside the confines of Australia? Shouldn't your latte have the most wonderful espresso, your agua fresca be super, uh, fresca and your Vietnamese Iced Coffee sing in your veins? Ever had a Smokin' Cuban? A Kimchi Reuben? A Banh Mi that makes you rue the day you never considered the lowly daikon? A coconut cream Macaron in one hand and a coconut Macaroon in the other?

I can make all of this happen. And more. Maybe twice.

I've been baking for farmer's markets and festivals for several years now but have been unable to expand my sales list because I am a cottage business. Once I'm in my mobile kitchen, the world is OUR oyster. I promise not to make sorbet out of it.  (Okay, that's a lie. It could be good!)

Bourbon caramel ice cream in the summer, Tuscan Beef Stew in the winter, year round Americanos and Macchiatos.  Lunch and Coffee subscriptions, cookies & milk delivery, festivals, wineries, breweries and more.  

And don't forget about guest baristas and bakers. I know some of the most amazing people with incredible ideas. If Taylor Swift can have guest singers, I can swing a surprise brewer or two.

Risks & Challenges

Risks and Challenges? Nah, not a one. Sigh. I jest.

 - I could lose a battle with a taco truck and get a bad parking spot. Guess I'd just take to Twitter so you can find me.

 - I could lose my recipe files and have to go off the grid, pulling smudgey recipe cards out of my filing cabinet. Okay, this wouldn't be so bad. 

-  I could develop an extreme sensitivity to caffeine.  Oh, hahahahahahaha! I can't even type that with a straight face. 

There are risks and challenges in everything.  And I have contingency plans.  And contingency plans on top of that.  The Ginger rolls his eyes each time I suggest a new component to the business but I'm committed to doing what I have to do to be where you want me to be with what I think you want to eat and drink - even if you don't know it yet. 

Other Ways You Can Help

No cash, no problem. Just pass this one to anyone who might be inclined to proselytize the beauty of bread or the ecstasy in a shot of espresso cloaked in a chrome short bus sporting a sugar skull made of produce.  (Is that sentence anywhere close to grammatically correct?)  

I am not someone who is comfortable with an entreaty - of any sort.  No hard sell really.  I just want to wake up and spend the day doing what I love to do: make coffee, make food and talk to people all day while doing it.  I hope this campaign puts me over the finish line.

story:
New Perk

$50 Holidays Gift - Challah for Hunger Long Sleeve T!

Looking for the perfect gift this holiday season? Give your friends and family a Challah for Hunger long sleeve t-shirt! Available in S, M, L and XL. Will ship by December 4th*. 

*We will email you for the name and address of the recipient.

Summary

Challah for Hunger brings people together to bake and sell challah to raise funds and awareness for social justice causes. We are a chapter model, currently working with 78 chapters on college campuses. 

Our goal is to expand our network to 100 active chapters by the end of the 2016-2017 school year. The more chapters we have today, the more leaders we train for tomorrow. 100 active chapters = 3,500+ social change leaders = $150,000 to fight hunger globally and locally. 

We need to raise $30,000 to significantly expand our core operations to support this growth.  

When you give to Challah for Hunger, you double your impact: (1) you invest in the future leaders of our community and (2) support local and global efforts to end hunger.

The Project

Challah for Hunger is a model for young people to meet, explore their mutual responsibility to heal the world through activism and philanthropy, and engage in community and Jewish tradition. Volunteers at 78 chapters around the world, mostly on college, campuses bake and sell challah and donate their earnings to non-profits working to end hunger around the world.

During the #ChallahDays we need to raise $30,000 to significantly expand our headquarters to support our volunteers and expand our network to 100 chapters.

In the past three years, we’ve increased the number of chapters we support and individuals we reach by 37.5%. In 2013, we supported 56 chapters. Today, we have 78 active chapters. At the start of the 2012-2013 school year, we reached 1,200 regular volunteers. In 2014-2015 we’ve reached 3,000 regular volunteers and those volunteers engaged 36,713 people through their work on campus and in their communities.

In order to support chapter growth, we’ve nearly doubled our budget over the past two years. In 2013, our budget was $199,056 and our 2015 budget is $361,304. Over the next two years, we expect to grow our budget to $475,000 to meet program needs. We need your help to grow our budget!

We need your help to better assist our students and reach 100 active chapters by the end of the 2016-2017 school year.

$30,000 will support the growth of our chapter program to 100 active chapters by the end of the 2016-2017 school year. This funding will allow us to:

  • Provide additional staff support - we can visit more chapters and dedicate more time to mentoring student leaders

  • Create and distribute more resources, like advocacy tool kits, recipes, and start up training materials

  • Facilitate more training opportunities, like our annual leadership summits which bring together more than 125 students from chapters for 2 days of leadership development trainings

Perks

When you support our campaign, you’ll receive:

$36 - Challah for Hunger Sticker
$75 - Challah for Hunger frisbee
$100 - Customized Bakers Hat
$100 - Challah for Hunger tote bag
$250 - Customized Apron
$1,000 - DIY Challah: Basket of goodies
$2,500 - Challah baking class
$5,000- ChallahDay with Carly and Liz


About Challah for Hunger

Eli Winkelman started Challah for Hunger as a student at Scripps College in 2004. She missed baking challah with her family, and was looking for a connection to the Jewish community at her school. To solve this, Eli began baking challah with friends, and quickly realized she and her friends could use challah-baking to mobilize and educate others. They began selling the challah and donating the profits to social justice causes. Word of Eli’s project spread, and soon Eli was guiding students, from all corners of the globe, as they started their own Challah for Hunger chapters.


A decade after Eli’s first challah sale, Challah for Hunger continues to thrive. Currently, thousands of volunteers on 78 campuses across the US, Canada, Australia, and England gather on a regular basis to continue the centuries-old tradition of baking challah together in an inclusive environment. For all the volunteers and many of the customers, Challah for Hunger provides opportunities to be involved in a fun and dedicated community, address humanitarian problems, develop and practice new skills, and gain business and leadership experience.

Impact

Since 2004 we've: 
  • Raised $800,000+ for hunger relief and social justice causes
  • Baked and sold 200,000 loaves of challah
  • Expanded to include 78 chapters around the world
  • Engaged 8,000 student change agents

During the 2014-2015 school year: 

  • 3,000 students participated in baking and selling challah and educating their peers about global and local hunger issues
  • 7,000 students supported Challah for Hunger by purchasing our homemade challah
  • $175,000 donated to local and international organizations, including our philanthropic and advocacy partner MAZON: A Jewish Response to Hunger.

When we asked participants to share how Challah for Hunger has transformed their lives, here’s what we found:

  • 86% increased their understanding and communication of the importance of giving. 
  • 84% increased their likelihood to stay involved in leadership.
  • 77% of respondents answered that CfH positively contributed to their Jewish identity to a good or great extent.
  • 75% of respondents answered that CfH supported them in making responsible philanthropy choices to a good or great extent.
  • 70% increased their awareness of hunger issues.


Honors

  • Featured in President Bill Clinton’s book “Giving: How each of us can change the world,” 
  • Named one of the most innovative Jewish organizations in North America by Slingshot  four times
  • Participated in Presentense fellowship twice! (The only organization to do so) Founder Eli Winkelman participated in the Global Summer Institute in 2007 and CEO Carly Zimmerman participated in the Tribe 12 Fellowship in 2014

Our Team

With a decade under our belts, we are uniquely qualified to inspire the next generation of change agents. Challah for Hunger is led by two chapter alumnae - Carly Zimmerman, CEO and Liz Smulian, Board Chair - who have experienced first-hand the joys and challenges of making change at the chapter level. Our small, but mighty professional team and incredible volunteers - including a network of 300+ alumni and powerhouse board of directors - have grown the organization by leaps and bounds.

You can help by:

  1. Making a donation and inviting friends and family to make a contribution.

  2. Follow us on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram 

  3. Post a Challah Selfie and use hashtag #ChallahDays

  4. Participate in a Challah tweet-up

  5. Buy a challah from a chapter near you!
